channel.title: Crashing Runescape Server?
channel.description: I was thinking, that is it possible to crash Runescapes server/servers with a server crasher (designed for private servers) IF you'd know their IP and port. So I used VisualRoute to find their IP it is 64.37.71.203 although the port is needed also. Don't know that will this work, will their firewall block it or something else. Try for yourself. If some "mastermind" figures this out, who knows what would happen? :| ServerCrasher is attached ( The creator of the server crasher is rs2crasher ).

item.title: Crashing Runescape Server?
item.dc:creator: @regecks1 regecks`
item.description:
@regecks1 wrote:

I’d be inclined to say that the server was coded in C++, despite what pplsuqbawls will probably try to tell you. I think Andrew/other main coders personally prefer C as a programming language, looking at their code, they use very little Java API, and a lot of binary maths (yes I realise it’s a game and that’s going to happen, but it’s still pretty excessive). Their OOP usage is pretty shithouse, and there are lot of similarities to the way C applications are coded.

Personally I think only the client is made in Java, to make the game easily playable and accessible. I think the server would run smoother/faster using C, giving them far more control over memory allocation etc.

Edit: Ignore everything I said above, it’s all lies.

Read full topic

item.title: Crashing Runescape Server?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Vipsta:

I really hate to bring up such an old post, but my bullshit detector went off tenfold.

As did mine when reading this.

Vipsta:

First of all, to the person that suggested they use 8-9 programming languages? Thats retarded. They coded the core of the RuneScape server in Java, and use a lighter version of Java (RuneScript) to code the actual interractions between objects and all. However, stuff like encryption, authentication, etc is coded in Java. Could it be possible they made it in a different language? Yes, but highly unlikely. This is because we already know they have a track record with Java. Why change? Also, if they wrote RS servers in something like C or C++, they would have to create a parser for RuneScript, which would essentially be re-creating the JVM.

Creating a whole new scripting language for a game engine? How un-farfetched… ever heard of Unrealscript?
While I am not saying the server isn’t written in Java, it’s perfectly reasonable to assume it is written in C++ also. They do hire C programmers, after all. And ask for C knowledge for their server administrators.

Vipsta:

Changing your IP for RuneScape is not hard at all. With the usage of a Virtual Private Network (VPN) you can start connections at an operating system level, as opposed to a proxy, which is simply making requests through the proxy server via the HTTP protocol. For obvious reasons, Jagex would not want to implement a proxy portion of their protocol. There are also other methods of “proxying” into RuneScape, which I will disclose at a later date.

This part just made no sense at all.

Vipsta:

And finally, crashing private servers has nothing to do with the coding of the server, but rather the bandwidth involved. I was able to crash servers easily by creating a connection, and once connected sending random bytes. Technically, you could trigger some type of exception in a basic private server by sending a packet with a buffer of 1,000,001 bytes to overload the 1,000,000 allocated in the core connection code. This is, however, going by my last look at the basic private server code, which was around August of 2006.

Actually, it has just as much to do with the server code, the servers are horrible.

Vipsta:

Want to know how to hack RS servers? Keep your eyes out for Solaris bugs. Since Jagex has sucked Sun Microsystem’s cock dry, I’d put money on them using Solaris servers. Although extremely rare, any remote command execution bug in Solaris or a service that RS servers are running (such as FTP) is a good opportunity to hack a Jagex server. Once inside, work fast and retrieve the most recent RS server build (probably in a Jar file, check the running processes for a location). Once you have that, post it here or message it to Mopar, and we’ll work on decompiling and possibly deobfuscating.

They don’t use Solaris servers, they run Debian. At least, they do for some things, so I don’t see why they wouldn’t for everything.

Read full topic

item.title: Crashing Runescape Server?
item.dc:creator: @Vipsta Vipsta
item.description:
@Vipsta wrote:

I really hate to bring up such an old post, but my bullshit detector went off tenfold.

First of all, to the person that suggested they use 8-9 programming languages? Thats retarded. They coded the core of the RuneScape server in Java, and use a lighter version of Java (RuneScript) to code the actual interractions between objects and all. However, stuff like encryption, authentication, etc is coded in Java. Could it be possible they made it in a different language? Yes, but highly unlikely. This is because we already know they have a track record with Java. Why change? Also, if they wrote RS servers in something like C or C++, they would have to create a parser for RuneScript, which would essentially be re-creating the JVM.

Changing your IP for RuneScape is not hard at all. With the usage of a Virtual Private Network (VPN) you can start connections at an operating system level, as opposed to a proxy, which is simply making requests through the proxy server via the HTTP protocol. For obvious reasons, Jagex would not want to implement a proxy portion of their protocol. There are also other methods of “proxying” into RuneScape, which I will disclose at a later date.

And finally, crashing private servers has nothing to do with the coding of the server, but rather the bandwidth involved. I was able to crash servers easily by creating a connection, and once connected sending random bytes. Technically, you could trigger some type of exception in a basic private server by sending a packet with a buffer of 1,000,001 bytes to overload the 1,000,000 allocated in the core connection code. This is, however, going by my last look at the basic private server code, which was around August of 2006.

Want to know how to crash RS servers? First, gather around 1,000-2,000 zombie computers (yes, a botnet) and then have them flood the TCP port of one of RuneScape’s servers. Assuming that the bandwidth power of 1,000-2,000 zombie computers is equal to that of the cluster of servers that runs one RS world, you should be able to knock them out for a good hour or so. Other types of denial of service attacks could be helpful, but you have to remember these servers running RS are at top-of-the-line datacenters, which most likely employ methods to protect against SYN floods, and other classic denial of service methods.

Want to know how to hack RS servers? Keep your eyes out for Solaris bugs. Since Jagex has sucked Sun Microsystem’s cock dry, I’d put money on them using Solaris servers. Although extremely rare, any remote command execution bug in Solaris or a service that RS servers are running (such as FTP) is a good opportunity to hack a Jagex server. Once inside, work fast and retrieve the most recent RS server build (probably in a Jar file, check the running processes for a location). Once you have that, post it here or message it to Mopar, and we’ll work on decompiling and possibly deobfuscating.

Read full topic

item.title: Crashing Runescape Server?
item.dc:creator: @exe626 exe626
item.description:
@exe626 wrote:

[quote=“frank_, post:11, topic:64673”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=93810.msg975481#msg975481 date=1173137621]
I believe someone by the name of Odie5533 wrote a program to log thousands of accounts into a runescape server at once. However something like this must be updated every time runescape updates, and it is quite possible they have protection from this now.

The fact is that runescape servers aren’t coded by a bunch of 13 year olds who don’t really know java, and therefore are not easily crashed at all. The reason private servers are crashed so easy is because they do not check for valid logins, they assume if a socket is opened on their port that it is a valid client, so they go ahead and allocate the memory needed. If you do this too many times you will run out of memory and crash.
[/quote]that… and they will ip ban you[/quote]
Frank_,
Have you ever used a proxy?
Or could you be like some of us and change your ip lol

Read full topic

item.title: Crashing Runescape Server?
item.dc:creator: @exe626 exe626
item.description:
@exe626 wrote:

Ok peoples, for one… This won’t work with his program,
We use loops and strings and eventually end up in something called ‘spaghetti’ when making our ‘servers’
They don’t use loops, they use different languages as well, if they coded it in java only, it would end up a horrid mess and be hack regularly, just like rsc was before the massive update.
Now I belive they run with 8 or 9 different programming languages to prevent such things because you would have to have a cracker resolve each of these languages at the same time, and nobody in this community has a computer ‘willing enough’ to do something like that.

If you could somehow come up with the virtual power and an amazing cracker to do something like that, good job… but until then, they remain un-harmed…

Read full topic

The fact is that runescape servers aren’t coded by a bunch of 13 year olds who don’t really know java, and therefore are not easily crashed at all. The reason private servers are crashed so easy is because they do not check for valid logins, they assume if a socket is opened on their port that it is a valid client, so they go ahead and allocate the memory needed. item.title: Crashing Runescape Server?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

I believe someone by the name of Odie5533 wrote a program to log thousands of accounts into a runescape server at once. However something like this must be updated every time runescape updates, and it is quite possible they have protection from this now.

The fact is that runescape servers aren’t coded by a bunch of 13 year olds who don’t really know java, and therefore are not easily crashed at all. The reason private servers are crashed so easy is because they do not check for valid logins, they assume if a socket is opened on their port that it is a valid client, so they go ahead and allocate the memory needed. If you do this too many times you will run out of memory and crash.

Read full topic
